Description: Rectangular mould-made plaque in glazed composition, from a foundation deposit.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Great Temenos, From the pylon of Ptolemy II in the Egyptian temple-enclosure, NE corner
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This object was not yet seen. At least six foundation deposits were discovered in Ptolemy II gateway of the Great Temenos, one at each of the four corners and one at the northwest and southwest corners of a central hall (Petrie 1886, 28-31, pl. XXV-XXVI; Weinstein 1973, 376-378, no. 158). The content of these deposits is purely Egyptian in nature and is very similar to that of Late Period foundation deposits (see for example those discovered at Tell Nebesheh, Gemaiyeni and Tell Defenneh: Petrie 1888, 14-15, 40-42, 54-55, pl. V-VI, pl. XIX and XXI-XXIII). Naukratis foundation deposits can be further compared to several foundation deposits, mainly dated between the reigns of Philip III Arrhidaeus and Ptolemy IV, and discovered in various temple complexes of the Delta, at Coptos and in the Theban region (discussed in: Weinstein 1973, 352-363, Group I). The foundation deposits of this pylon provided several rectangular plaques made in various materials- notably different metals and stones, as well as fragments of raw material, such as lapis lazuli and turquoise. Three plaques in glazed composition, like this one, were also discovered: one in the north-east corner, one in the south-west one and one in the north-west one (Petrie 1886, 31, pl. XXV no. 20). According to Petrie’s list, this object was found at the north-east corner of the pylon. Petrie considered it to represent 'that material (green glazed sandy ware) used for decorations' (Petrie 1886, 29). In the frame of a foundation deposit, faience plaques can also act a symbolic or magical substitute material (on large and inscribed faience bricks from a Ramesses II foundation deposit in Qantir see: Weinstein 1973, 244-7, 254-257).
